column11: Rezoning - Only property owner(s) or authorized agents can petition
column12: Rezoning - Must submit a site plan, drawn to scale
column13: Rezoning - Meet with the Administrator before any PIM
column14: Rezoning - The application must be accompanied by a fee
column15: Rezoning - The Administrator may require multiple copies
column16: Rezoning - The Planning Board may request additional information
column17: Rezoning - Schedule PIM after the complete application and fees are submitted
column18: Rezoning - Applicant provides agenda, schedule, location for PIM
column20: Rezoning - Significant changes to proposal after PIM may require a second PIM
column21: Rezoning - Publish a public notice in the Gaston Gazette 10-25 days before PIM
column22: Rezoning - Mail notice to nearby property owners 10 days before PIM
column23: Rezoning - Applicant shall furnish the Town with mailing labels
column24: Rezoning - Post a public notice sign on the property 10 days before PIM
column25: Rezoning - Applicant can revise the application based on PIM feedback
column26: Rezoning - Submit revised application within 30 days after PIM
column28: Rezoning - Planning Board has 45 days to make a recommendation
column30: Rezoning - Action by Board of Commissioners
column31: Minor Subdivision - Submit two mylar prints and five paper prints of the final plat
column32: Minor Subdivision - Ensure the Final Plat Scale is at least 1‚Äù ‚Äì 100 Feet
column33: Minor Subdivision - Ensure Plat is prepared by a licensed Land Surveyor in NC
column34: Minor Subdivision - Ensure the appropriate site plan fee is included
column35: Minor Subdivision - Application/Plat is submitted to Administrator
column36: Minor Subdivision - TRC has 30 days from complete application submission to approve or disapprove
column37: Minor Subdivision - Notify Applicant of decision within 5 Days
column38: Minor Subdivision - Resubmit revised plat within 30 days of disapproval
column39: Minor Subdivision - If approved by TRC, furnish the Administrator with a digital copy
column40: Minor Subdivision - The administrator shall indicate the approval of the final plat
column42: Major Subdivision - Submit a Subdivision Application of Preliminary Plat at least 15 days prior
column43: Major Subdivision - Submit at least five paper copies of the preliminary plat
column44: Major Subdivision - Review by the Technical Review Committee
column45: Major Subdivision - Review by the Planning Board
column46: Major Subdivision - Review by the Board of Commissioners
column47: Major Subdivision - Submit five paper copies of the construction plan within one year
column48: Major Subdivision - Administrator sends plans to Town Engineer
column49: Major Subdivision - The Town Engineer has up to 45 Days for initial comments
column50: Major Subdivision - Final approval of the construction plan by the Town Engineer
column51: Major Subdivision - After approval, proceed with construction as per the approved plan
column52: Major Subdivision - Submit two mylar copies, twelve prints, and a digital format copy
column53: Major Subdivision - TRC reviews the final plat for compliance
column54: Major Subdivision - Administrator shall notify the subdivider of the decisions
column55: Major Subdivision - Record the approved final plat with the register of deeds

column6: Located just east of the South New Hope Road and Armstrong Ford Road Intersection, Redhawk Phase I is a ±114.82 acre undeveloped site, currently conditionally zoned for the development of 144 townhomes, and 213 single-family detached homes.

Located along South New Hope Road and just south of Redhawk Phase I, Redhawk Phase II is a ±157.94-acre undeveloped site, currently conditionally zoned for the development of 129 townhomes, and 191-single-family detached homes.
Located along the Redhawk Phase II's southern boundary, Redhawk Phase III is a ±150.2-acre undeveloped site, currently conditionally zoned for the development of 393-single family detached homes.

Located just south of Redhawk Phase III, and the proposed Catawba Crossing, Redhawk Phase IV is a ±53-acre undeveloped site, currently conditionally zoned for the development of up to one million square feet of gross floor area of buisness park and/or light industrial uses, and municipal servivces.

Located along South New Hope Road and inbetween Belvon Drive/Stowe Road, The Towns at Cramerton is a 37.97-acre undeveloped site, undergoing the rezoning process to allow for 36 townhomes and 188 single-family detached homes.

Located along the South Fork Catawba River and just south of Cramer Mountain Road, Villages at Cramerton Mills Phases 1A and 1B is complete, and allowed for the development of 101 single-family detached homes.
Located along Cramer Mountain Road, Villages at Cramerton Mills Phase 1C is a ±16.59-acre undeveloped site, currently under construction of 68 townhomes.
Located along Hamrick Road, Villages at Cramerton Mills Phase 1D is a ±21.17-acre undeveloped site, currently conditionally zoned for the development of 40 single-family detached homes.

Located at the intersection of South New Hope Road and Cramer Mountain Road, Village at Cramerton Mills Phase 1E (Townhomes at Cramerton) is almost complete, and allowed for the development of 61 townhomes and ~32,000 square feet of commerical.
Located at the intersection of South New Hope Road and Cramer Mountain Road, Village at Cramerton Mills Phase 2E is under construction, and is currently approved for the development of 40 townhomes.
Located along Hamrick Road, Villages at Cramerton Mills Phase 1F is a ±34.69-acre site, currently conditionally zoned for the development of 60 townhomes and 62 single-family-detached homes.

column3: Court Yards at New Hope Road
column6: Located at the intersection of South New Hope Road and New Style Way, the Court Yards at New Hope Road is a ±13.42-acre site conditionally zoned to allow for 30 single-family detached lots, as well as 12,000 square feet of commericaly development fronting South New Hope Road.
Located just south of Wilkinson Blvd, Cramerton Village Drive is a ±28.41 acre undeveloped site, undergoing the rezoning process to allow for 66 single-family attached lots.
